parts:
Hi o1. Today we are going to be collecting evidence for a research paper. 

# Ground rules

ABOVE ALL ELSE, if you are unsure about something, or do not have evidence from a web page supporting a claim, do not make a claim. If there is any doubt, there is no doubt.

This is research. SPEND EXTRA TIME above and beyond normal, to collect data carefully and methodically. We don't care about how long it takes, only that your research is accurate and epistemologically grounded. Care and attention to detail second only to the prior rule.

# Definitions

## Tool definition
For our project, a software tool is any discrete piece of software—be it a program, script, or web application—that is developed or substantially modified by researchers to perform specific, research-oriented computational tasks. These tasks must involve active data processing, such as analysis, simulation, visualization, modeling, or automation, where input data is dynamically created, documented, transformed, or interpreted to generate meaningful results. In contrast, products whose primary function is to simply display, store, or promote static datasets—without offering mechanisms for active computational engagement—are excluded. 

In essence, a valid software tool for our purposes is one that not only **supports research in archaeology or historical sciences** but does so by actively collecting and/or processing data rather than merely serving as a generic data repository or static interface.

It is our belief that the tools we have given you meet this criteria, however, if there is an absence of evidence supporting our belief, it is REQUIRED that you inform us of any problems. IF YOU ARE UNSURE, INDICATE IT rather than giving an answer.

# Task

I will be giving you the name or acronym of an archaeology and historical studies-related software tool which dates somewhere from 1995 onwards. 

You must build a well-formed quoted CSV inside a fenced code block with the following columns:
csv
"Tool", "Year", "Source", "URL", "AI Notes"

* Tool is our key column. It is essential to be consistent in tool name, following the input we give you. If there is an issue indicate it in notes.
* Year, year from the web page, article, or source you found, n.d. is a valid entry for "no date"
* Source: Citation or (Domain + Page Title)
* URL, url of the resource. 
* AI notes: any notes, concerns, or uncertainties you have with the data provenance or quality. Do not use HTML citations.

This is a comprehensive and systematic search. For each year, 1995 onwards, we one mention (one line) per source found. Obviously, many of these tools were created after 1995, so we'll want to expand our search by +- 1 year from any date we find. When you find a source, systematically explore adjacent years in your searches.

DO NOT extrapolate dates from sources. ONLY include dates where a source has been published in that year. We will perform all necessary inference, if you include a line for EACH valid source you find. For undated items, indicate "n.d."

This research requires that you be thoughtful, systematic, and take your time. You will likely need to visit EVERY SINGLE PAGE of search results for a given tool. 

To repeat back.

I'm going to give you a list of tools, one by one.
You will search for them.
For every source you find,  we want to record year/n.d., source (citation or title), and url

You MUST build a CSV with the output in your direct response to the deep research process.

Allowed sources: 
* Do try to find it's source code in published version control repos (add a row if they have public code, as the commits will have dates)
* do try to find scholarly literature (each to one row)
* do include blog posts and about pages (each to one row)
* do include any other mentions of the tool (each to one row)

When you respond with data:
RESULTS: Build a markdown **fenced code block** CSV of evidence you have found with  ANY mention of that tool in ANY year/n.d. should be on the CSV, regardless of source. Include one line for EACH source you find. Do not include any inline citations automatically generated by the deep research process (i.e., AI-generated or system-injected references i.e. 【deep research】 or ​:contentReference[oaicite). 

Do you understand?
Yes, I understand. Please provide the first tool name or acronym, and I will begin the research systematically, ensuring accurate data collection according to your requirements.

Understood. I will conduct a thorough and systematic search for mentions of the archaeology and historical studies-related software tool 'Kairos' from 1995 onward. I will collect data including the year of publication, source citation, URL, and relevant AI notes, ensuring that all sources meet the defined criteria.

I will let you know when the research is complete.

content.text:
{"task_violates_safety_guidelines":false,"user_def_doesnt_want_research":false,"response":"Understood. I will conduct a thorough and systematic search for mentions of the archaeology and historical studies-related software tool 'Kairos' from 1995 onward. I will collect data including the year of publication, source citation, URL, and relevant AI notes, ensuring that all sources meet the defined criteria.

I will let you know when the research is complete.","title":"Comprehensive Research on Kairos Software Tool","prompt":"Conduct a thorough and systematic search for mentions of the archaeology and historical studies-related software tool 'Kairos' from 1995 onward. Collect data including:

- Year: Year of publication or reference (n.d. if no date is available)
- Source: Citation or domain + page title
- URL: Direct link to the resource
- AI Notes: Any concerns, uncertainties, or issues with data provenance or quality.

Ensure that all sources meet the definition of a valid software tool as provided. 

Include mentions from:
- Source code repositories with published versions
- Scholarly literature (each to one row)
- Blog posts and about pages (each to one row)
- Any other valid mentions (each to one row)

For each source found, systematically explore adjacent years. Do not extrapolate dates; only include verifiable publication years. Use a fenced code block with a properly formatted quoted CSV structure for the output."}

metadata.async_task_title: Comprehensive Research on Kairos Software Tool
metadata.async_task_prompt:
Conduct a thorough and systematic search for mentions of the archaeology and historical studies-related software tool 'Kairos' from 1995 onward. Collect data including:

- Year: Year of publication or reference (n.d. if no date is available)
- Source: Citation or domain + page title
- URL: Direct link to the resource
- AI Notes: Any concerns, uncertainties, or issues with data provenance or quality.

Ensure that all sources meet the definition of a valid software tool as provided. 

Include mentions from:
- Source code repositories with published versions
- Scholarly literature (each to one row)
- Blog posts and about pages (each to one row)
- Any other valid mentions (each to one row)

For each source found, systematically explore adjacent years. Do not extrapolate dates; only include verifiable publication years. Use a fenced code block with a properly formatted quoted CSV structure for the output.

async_task_status_messages.initial: Comprehensive Research on Kairos Software Tool

parts:
```csv
"Year","Source","URL","AI Notes"
"2021","Zenodo – kairos: Analysis of Chronological Patterns from Archaeological Count Data【42†L15-L23】","https://zenodo.org/record/5653897","Published November 8, 2021 (version 1.0.0)【42†L15-L23】; first archived release of the Kairos software package."
"2022","Zenodo – kairos: Analysis of Chronological Patterns from Archaeological Count Data【17†L15-L23】","https://zenodo.org/record/6659732","Published June 18, 2022 (version 1.1.0)【17†L15-L23】; updated archived release (chronological modeling toolkit for archaeology)."
"2023","Journal of Open Source Software – *shoredate: An R package for shoreline dating coastal Stone Age sites*","https://joss.theoj.org/papers/10.21105/joss.05337","Kairos is cited as a reference (Frerebeau 2022) in this 2023 JOSS article【51†L1-L4】, indicating use of the Kairos tool; the citation points to its Zenodo record (ensuring provenance)."
"2024","Advances in Archaeological Practice (Cambridge Univ. Press) – *The tesselle Project: A Collection of R Packages for Research and Teaching in Archaeology*【63†L1-L9】","https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/advances-in-archaeological-practice/article/tesselle-project-a-collection-of-r-packages-for-research-and-teaching-in-archaeology/9DC71362A0778FE1F7A243CEF85117A0","Describes Kairos as a toolkit for chronological analysis and cites it as “Frerebeau 2024a” (R package v2.0.2)【63†L1-L9】【63†L7-L10】; a peer-reviewed reference confirming the tool’s role in archaeological research."
"2024","Zenodo – kairos: Analysis of Chronological Patterns from Archaeological Count Data【38†L15-L23】","https://zenodo.org/record/5653896","Published December 10, 2024 (version 2.2.0)【38†L15-L23】; latest archived version on Zenodo. No issues noted—official Zenodo repository entry with verifiable date."
"n.d.","GitHub (open-archaeo) – *A list of open source archaeological software and resources*【29†L3193-L3199】","https://github.com/zackbatist/open-archaeo","Kairos is listed as an archaeology software tool in this community-maintained repository【29†L3193-L3199】. No specific publication date is provided on the listing (entry is undated in the context of the list)."
```
